simulated_ratings.title: Naufragio (1978)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A quietly aching portrait of longing and projection that fits my love for intimate, character-driven drama.

simulated_ratings.title: Frankie (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-dappled, contemplative ensemble work about mortality and family that I found gently affecting.

simulated_ratings.title: Dead Silence (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric and fun with old-school spookiness, even if the mythology gets a bit pulpy.

simulated_ratings.title: Puppet Master X: Axis Rising (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Goofy lore and cheap thrills left me more amused than invested.

simulated_ratings.title: So Long, Stooge (1983)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A bruised, human crime drama about unlikely friendship that really landed with me.

simulated_ratings.title: For the Love of a Dog (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweet but rote family stakes that felt too tidy for my taste.

simulated_ratings.title: Thomas Hart Benton (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Engaged me with art-as-people’s-history, a clear, muscular portrait of a singular painter.

simulated_ratings.title: Viva Algeria (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tough, empathetic, and politically alive—exactly the kind of social drama I gravitate toward.

simulated_ratings.title: Shopping (1994)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stylized, grimy youth-crime energy that scratches the genre itch without much depth.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hunted (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A premise I like, but the execution felt thin once the sun went down.

simulated_ratings.title: Randy Feltface: The Book of Randicus (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Playful, oddball philosophizing that gave me a steady stream of laughs.

simulated_ratings.title: Homecoming (1948)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic wartime romance with moral complication—old-fashioned but satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: Genocide (Konchû daisensô) (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Doomy, bonkers bug-apocalypse vibes I enjoyed in a midnight-movie way.

simulated_ratings.title: Evil Dead Trap 2: Hideki (1992)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Psychological, disorienting horror that burrowed under my skin.

simulated_ratings.title: The Doors Are Open (1968)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A potent time-capsule concert doc—more mood than insight, but still compelling.

simulated_ratings.title: Cucaracha, La (1998)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sweaty, down-and-dirty noir beats that entertain more than resonate.

simulated_ratings.title: Bone in the Throat (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: Arrow In The Dust (1954)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Solid, no-frills Western mechanics that I appreciated more than loved.

simulated_ratings.title: No Sex Please: We're British (1973)

simulated_ratings.title: Gladiator Cop (1995)

simulated_ratings.feeling: A shaggy, amiable crime-comedy with enough charm to carry me along.

simulated_ratings.title: Red Canyon (1949)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pleasant scenery and familiar Western romance that left a light impression.

simulated_ratings.title: Sunday in Peking (1956)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lyrical, observant travel-essay filmmaking that I found deeply inviting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Most Reluctant Convert: The Untold Story of C.S. Lewis (2021)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A thoughtful, talky conversion chronicle that intrigued more than it moved me.

simulated_ratings.title: Into the Forest (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender seasonal rhythms and small-town textures that quietly warmed me.

simulated_ratings.title: Charming Mass Suicide, A (Hurmaava joukkoitsemurha) (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny yet humane, balancing absurdity with surprising compassion.

simulated_ratings.title: The Arch (1969)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A breezy legal caper with a few clever turns but limited staying power.

simulated_ratings.title: Invisible Invaders (1959)

simulated_ratings.title: Project: ALF (1996)
